user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_redirect_fixed_rq_target:
```c
static void
send_redirect_fixed_rq_target (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  char *b;
  size_t fixed_uri_len;
  size_t i;
  size_t o;
  char *hdr_name;
  size_t hdr_name_len;

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING == c->state);
  mhd_assert (0 != c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.num_ws_in_uri);
  mhd_assert (c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.num_ws_in_uri <= \
              c->rq.req_target_len);
  fixed_uri_len = c->rq.req_target_len
                  + 2 * c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.num_ws_in_uri;
  if ( (fixed_uri_len + 200 > c->daemon->pool_size) ||
       (fixed_uri_len > MHD_MAX_FIXED_URI_LEN) ||
       (NULL == (b = malloc (fixed_uri_len + 1))) )
  {
    connection_close_error (c,
                            _ ("The request has whitespace character is " \
                               "in the URI and the URI is too large to " \
                               "send automatic redirect to fixed URI.\n"));
    return;
  }
  i = 0;
  o = 0;

  do
  {
    const char chr = c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.rq_tgt[i++];

    mhd_assert ('\r' != chr); /* Replaced during request line parsing */
    mhd_assert ('\n' != chr); /* Rejected during request line parsing */
    mhd_assert (0 != chr); /* Rejected during request line parsing */
    switch (chr)
    {
    case ' ':
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '2';
      b[o++] = '0';
      break;
    case '\t':
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '0';
      b[o++] = '9';
      break;
    case 0x0B:   /* VT (vertical tab) */
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '0';
      b[o++] = 'B';
      break;
    case 0x0C:   /* FF (form feed) */
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '0';
      b[o++] = 'C';
      break;
    default:
      b[o++] = chr;
      break;
    }
  } while (i < c->rq.req_target_len);
  mhd_assert (fixed_uri_len == o);
  b[o] = 0; /* Zero-terminate the result */

  hdr_name_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_LOCATION);
  hdr_name = malloc (hdr_name_len + 1);
  if (NULL != hdr_name)
  {
    memcpy (hdr_name,
            MHD_HTTP_HEADER_LOCATION,
            hdr_name_len + 1);
    /* hdr_name and b are free()d within this call */
    transmit_error_response_header (c,
                                    MHD_HTTP_MOVED_PERMANENTLY,
                                    RQ_TARGET_INVALID_CHAR,
                                    hdr_name,
                                    hdr_name_len,
                                    b,
                                    o);
    return;
  }
  free (b);
  connection_close_error (c,
                          _ ("The request has whitespace character is in the " \
                             "URI.\n"));
  return;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function send_redirect_fixed_rq_target:
#define MHD_MAX_FIXED_URI_LEN (64*1024)
...
#define MHD_HTTP_MOVED_PERMANENTLY 301
...
#define RQ_TARGET_INVALID_CHAR "<html>""<head><title>Request broken</title></head>""<body>HTTP request has invalid characters in ""the request-target.</body>""</html>"
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are used in the presented function body. I checked for common vendor/GCC/clang-specific extensions and constructs that are typically documented as extensions (and would therefore trigger Rule 1.2):

- No use of __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_* functions, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, case-range labels, or other GCC/clang-specific tokens.
- No use of Microsoft extensions (e.g. __stdcall, __declspec), no assembler blocks, no inline assembler, no nonstandard keywords.
- No use of compound literals, variable-length arrays, or other constructs that would be extensions beyond standard ISO C in most compilers (the code uses only standard types and literals such as 0x0B/0x0C, standard case labels, and normal string literal concatenation).
- Preprocessor line-continuation (backslashes) and adjacent string literal concatenation are standard C features, not compiler extensions.

Note: several identifiers in the snippet are macros or external symbols (mhd_assert, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_LOCATION, _, transmit_error_response_header, connection_close_error, etc.). If any of those macros or functions expand to or use compiler-specific extensions (for example, use __attribute__ or builtin intrinsics), that would be a Rule 1.2 violation — but such expansions are not visible in this function body. Therefore, based on the code shown here, there are no suspicious fragments to investigate for Rule 1.2. If you want, I can inspect the definitions of those macros/externals to ensure they do not hide extensions.
